Magnetic properties of the materials 3.3 Photo-Fenton degradation results 3.3.1 Effect of solution pH on photo-Fenton degradation of OII 3.3.2 Photo-Fenton degradation of OII by various samples 3.3.3 Visible light assisted Fenton-like degradation of Orange II on Ni3Fe/Fe3O4 magnetic catalyst prepared from spent FeNi layered double hydroxide Minwang Laipan a b Runliang Zhu a ⁎ Jianxi Zhu a Hongping He a a Key Laboratory of Mineralogy and Metallogeny, Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Mineral Physics and Material Research & Development, Guangzhou 510640, China Key Laboratory of Mineralogy and Metallogeny Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences; Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Mineral Physics and Material Research & Development Guangzhou 510640 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 20 85297603. Graphical abstract Magnetic Ni3Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst was prepared by using spent FeNi layered double hydroxide derived from the adsorption of organic dyes as precursor via heat treatment under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray diffraction results indicated that the obtained materials were composed of Ni3Fe and Fe3O4. Thermogravimetric analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and thermomagnetic curves characterization results demonstrated that Fe3+ and Ni2+ could be reduced to low valence by organic contaminants, and the obtained materials possessed strong magnetism. Visible light assisted Fenton-like experiment results showed that the obtained materials possessed high catalytic activities and the degradations at pH of 3–6 and pH 7 preferred to followed Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Eley–Rideal mechanism, respectively. In addition, the possible effects of Fe0 and Ni species were briefly discussed as well. On the other hand, comparing to the heated products of FeNi layered double hydroxide the obtained materials presented much superiority including variety in metal valences, higher amount of −OH surface group, stronger magnetism and higher Curie point, and higher catalytic activities. This work provided a facile method for reutilizing the spent layered double hydroxide adsorbent with special metal elements (e.g., Fe and Ni) as well as synthesizing functional material (e.g., catalyst). Keywords FeNi layered double hydroxide Spent adsorbent reutilizing Magnetic catalyst Photo-Fenton Degradation Nomenclature OII Orange II FeNi-LDH FeNi layered double hydroxide S-FeNi-LDH Spent FeNi-LDH resulted from the adsorption of OII by FeNi-LDH S-FeNi-600 Thermal treatment product of the spent FeNi-LDH at 600°C S-FeNi-800 Thermal treatment product of the spent FeNi-LDH at 800°C S-FeNi-1000 Thermal treatment product of the spent FeNi-LDH at 1000°C FeNi-600 Thermal treatment product of the FeNi-LDH at 600°C FeNi-800 Thermal treatment product of the FeNi-LDH at 800°C FeNi-1000 Thermal treatment product of the FeNi-LDH at 1000°C 1 Introduction Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), one type of anionic clays, have been regarded as promising adsorbents for the removal of anionic dyes from wastewater because of their high adsorption efficiency as well as low cost in easily and massively synthesizing with tunable chemical compositions [1–5]. These merits may promote the large-scale application of LDHs in dye effluents treatment, which, however, will result in large amount of spent LDHs adsorbents. As such, proper disposal/reutilization of the spent adsorbents needs serious concerns. Recently, several studies utilized the spent LDHs after treatment of dye effluents as nanofiller or colorant filler for polymer materials, and the results demonstrated to be quite satisfying [6,7]. These studies enlighten us that spent LDHs can be precursors for synthesizing functional materials. In our recent work, the spent LDH was carbonized to obtain carbon/metal oxides complexes, which were further washed with acid to synthesize mesoporous carbon materials with large specific surface areas (>1400m2/g) [8]. On the other hand, as there are many studies focusing on using the heated products of LDHs with special metals (i.e., the double metal oxides) as catalysts [9–12], it is worth investigating whether the obtained carbon/metal oxides complexes from spent LDHs can be used as catalysts as well. Furthermore, as the adsorbed organic contaminants can be carbonized into porous carbon or act as reductant under the heating process, the catalytic properties of the obtained products may be different from those double metal oxides made from LDHs. As such, the difference in catalytic activities of these two kinds of heated products, and the role of the adsorbed organic contaminants in catalyst synthesis is worth studying as well. In this work, we studied the role of the adsorbed organic contaminants in materials synthesis and compared the catalytic activities of these two kinds of heated products based on Fenton-like reaction, one type of the most concerned catalysis reactions. A spent FeNi layered double hydroxide (S-FeNi-LDH) derived from the adsorption of anionic dye Orange II (OII) (Supplementary material, Fig. S1) was selected as a representative of spent LDHs, and then it was thermal treated under nitrogen protection at 600–1000°C to get the catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TG), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), elemental analysis, N2 adsorption–desorption, and thermomagnetic (k–T) analysis were utilized to determine the effects of the organic contaminant in materials synthesis. On the other hand, visible light assisted Fenton-like degradation of OII experiments were used to evaluate the differences in catalytic activities. Finally, the possible OII degradation mechanism on the obtained materials from S-FeNi-LDH was briefly discussed. This work could be of some values in spent LDH adsorbent reutilizing as well as functional material (e.g., catalyst) synthesizing. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Preparation of FeNi-LDH FeNi-LDH (molar ratio of Fe3+/Ni2+ =1) was synthesized using conventional co-precipitation method [13–15]. Firstly, two 400mL solutions were prepared, one containing 0.5mol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (AR) and 0.5mol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (AR), and the other containing 1.5mol sodium hydroxide and 0.3mol sodium carbonate. Then, the two solutions were added dropwise into a beaker (containing 200mL of ultrapure water) under vigorous stirring at room temperature. The pH was maintained at 10±0.1 using Chroma CPH-2 automatic pH controller. The generated heavy gel was crystallized at 75°C for 18h. After that, the product was centrifuged and washed with ultrapure water until the supernatant pH was below 8 before drying at 80°C overnight. 2.2 Thermal treatment of the spent FeNi-LDH About 5g of FeNi-LDH were added into 0.5L OII solution (10g/L) under vigorous stirring at room temperature (25°C) to generate the S-FeNi-LDH. After a given contact time for adsorption (6h), the solid was separated by centrifugation, and finally OII loading amount was 264.6mg/g. Then, the collected S-FeNi-LDH was loaded to a crucible, and heated in a temperature-controlled tubular furnace to the desired temperature (600–1000°C) under the protection of nitrogen. The heating rate was 5°C/min, and the samples were maintained at the target temperature for 3h. After cooling down to room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere, the obtained materials were milled until particle sizes finer than 200 meshes before storing in desiccator over silica gel. The materials obtained under the heating temperature of 600, 800, and 1000°C herein were referred to as S-FeNi-600, S-FeNi-800, and S-FeNi-1000, respectively. For comparative purposes, FeNi-LDH was also heated under the same conditions, and the resulting materials were named as FeNi-600, FeNi-800, and FeNi-1000, respectively. 2.3 Characterization methods XRD patterns of the samples were measured on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation operating at 40kV and 40mA. The patterns were recorded over the 2θ range from 3 to 80° with a scan speed of 2°/min using a bracket sample holder. The XPS spectra of the elements in the materials were recorded using a Kα X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, UK) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. All spectra were calibrated using adventitious C 1s peak with a fixed value of 284.8eV. After calibration, the background from each spectrum was subtracted using a Shirley-type background to remove most of the extrinsic loss structure. The high resolution spectra of Fe 2p were analyzed by using peaks corresponding to the GS multiplets [16,17]. TG analysis was carried out on a Netzsch STA 490 PC thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10°C/min in the temperature range from 30 to 1000°C under air atmosphere. The flow rate was 60mL/min. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elementar Vario EL III Universal CHNOS Elemental Analyzer. Thermomagnetic curves (k–T) were recorded to examine magnetism of the materials [18,19] using CS4 furnace apparatus in cooperation with the MFK1-FA Kappabridge under a constant magnetic field intensity of 400A/m. The heating rate was 10°C/min from room temperature up to 700°C and back to room temperature under argon atmosphere. The morphology and structure of the materials were analyzed by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-100CX, JEOL) at an acceleration voltage of 80kV. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the materials were determined at 77K using an ASAP 2020 Surface Area & Pore Size Analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation). The Zeta Potentials of all the samples were determined by Mastersizer NANO ZS (Malvern Instrument Limited, England). 2.4 Photocatalytic experiments To verify the catalytic properties of the obtained materials, visible-light assisted Fenton experiments for degradation of OII were carried out at a photoreactor (equipped with UV light filters; BL-GHX-V, China) with a 400W metal halide lamp (420–780nm, 21.5–23.0mw/cm2). Appropriate amounts of a catalyst were dispersed into an OII solution (100mg/L) at a catalyst dose of 0.2g/L. The initial pH of OII solution was adjusted using 0.1mol/L HNO3 and NaOH. Notably, the adding of catalysts presented negligible influence to the pH of OII solution. All experiments were carried out under room temperature with constantly stirring to make the catalyst good dispersion. The degradation was initiated by turning on the light and adding the oxidant H2O2 into the solution (5mmol/L). At given intervals, the reaction solution was sampled and filtered through 0.22μm membrane for OII photodegradation profile analysis by UV–vis spectrophotometer (PE Lambda 850) at 485nm. The concentrations of the leached Fe/Ni cations during the degradation were measured on a Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (PE AAnalyst 400). Total organic carbon (TOC) concentration was analyzed in a Shimadzu TOC-VCPH analyzer to evaluate the mineralization of dyes. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characterization results of the materials The XRD pattern of FeNi-LDH showed that only the characteristic reflections belonging to LDHs were presented (Fig. S2), which indicated that FeNi-LDH was well crystallized. As for the heated products, the results showed that FeNi-600, FeNi-800, and FeNi-1000 were mainly composed by trevorite (PDF # 86-2267, NiFe2O4). However, S-FeNi-600, S-FeNi-800, and S-FeNi-1000 mainly contained magnetite (PDF # 74-0748, Fe3O4) and awaruite (PDF # 88-1715, Ni3Fe) (Fig. 1 ). These different XRD characterization results illustrated that Fe/Ni elements could be reduced under heating in the presence of organic dyes and thus formed different minerals. The XPS characterization results also suggested the formation of different minerals for the heated products. The Fe 2p3/2 envelopes were fitted using the GS multiplets, and the results demonstrated that the materials obtained from FeNi-LDH and S-FeNi-LDH involved trevorite and magnetite species, respectively [16] (Fig. 2 , Table 1 ), well in agreement with the XRD results. From Ni 2p spectra, the peak belonging to Ni0 (852.7eV) [20,21] could be clearly seen on S-FeNi-600, S-FeNi-800, and S-FeNi-1000 (but not on those materials obtained from heated FeNi-LDH), which further indicated the presence of awaruite on them. However, no obvious peaks of Fe0 (706.6eV) [16] could be observed in the Fe 2p spectra, probably because of the surface oxidation or limited amount of Fe0. On the other hand, O 1s spectra suggested that S-FeNi-600, S-FeNi-800, and S-FeNi-1000 possessed larger amounts of surface hydroxyl than their counterparts from the heated FeNi-LDH [22] (Fig. S3), which might result from the substitution of Fe3+ by Ni2+ in magnetite [23]. TG analysis results showed that no obvious weight loss or gaining for FeNi-600, FeNi-800, and FeNi-1000 (Fig. S4), suggesting the absence of low valence species. However, obvious weight gaining processes for all the materials obtained from heated S-FeNi-LDH were showed at temperature range of 400–1000°C (Fig. 3 ), which demonstrated the existence of low valence species, and they could be oxidized during the calcination in air atmosphere. In addition, the mass loss from 100 to 400°C, arising from the dehydroxylation process, was more obvious for those samples obtained using S-FeNi-LDH, in accordance with above XPS results. The DSC curves showed that the exothermicity of the obtained materials was in the order: S-FeNi-600>S-FeNi-800>S-FeNi-1000, while the temperatures of the maximum exothermic peak were in the reverse order (Fig. 3). These results suggested that the thermal stability of them was direct correlation to their heating temperature during the synthesis process. Elemental analysis results revealed that negligible amount of carbon existed in these obtained materials from S-FeNi-LDH (Table 2 ), which suggested that carbon had been consumed during the heating process, probably by acting as reductant. This in combination with above characterization results suggested that OII could reduce Fe and Ni cations to various valences during thermal treatment, and the obtained materials might possess both magnetism and catalytic activities. TEM images showed that the particles of FeNi-600 and FeNi-800 were mostly in the uniform type with an average size of 100 and 450nm (Fig. 4 ), respectively. Conversely, S-FeNi-600 and S-FeNi-800 presented mainly irregular shapes of the particles with large particle size range from 250 to 350nm and 0.9 to 3.0μm, respectively. The irregular shapes of the particles should result from the mixture of Fe3O4 and Ni3Fe. N2 adsorption–desorption results showed that all of the samples possessed quite small surface areas (0.4–21.5m2/g, Table 2). Zeta potential measurement results showed that the Zeta potential of all samples presented a trend of decrease from positive potential to negative potential (Fig. 5 ). All of the heated products had a similar Isoelectric point (IEP) around pH of 3–4, but that of the heated products from S-FeNi-LDH were a bit higher than that of the products obtained from FeNi-LDH (Fig. 5, Table 2). 3.2 Magnetic properties of the materials Thermal variation in total susceptibility was utilized to examine the magnetism of the obtained materials [18,19]. The results showed that in the initial part of k–T curves, the susceptibilities of all the materials were either roughly constant or represented by a straight line of very low slope (i.e., not temperature-dependent) (Fig. 6 ), suggesting that the materials were of ferromagnetism [18]. On the other hand, these materials showed Curie temperature in the vicinity of 600°C, which illustrated the presence of magnetite or magnetite-like species [18]. The materials obtained from FeNi-LDH had similar Curie point around 569°C (Fig. S5), which suggested these materials were probably single magnetic specie (i.e., trevorite, consistent with the XRD results). However, the materials obtained from S-FeNi-LDH had Curie temperatures variation from 591 to 612°C (Fig. S5), which were larger than that of magnetite (576–587°C) [24,25]. The high Curie temperatures should be attributed to the presence of awaruite [26], in agreement with the XRD results. Mass susceptibility (x m) was always used for comparing the magnetism, and x m could be calculated according to the literature [18]. The x m values of all the materials at room temperature were calculated using CGS/SI units (Table 2). The results revealed that x m of the materials obtained from both FeNi-LDH and S-FeNi-LDH increased firstly and then decreased with further rising thermal treatment temperature (from 600 to 1000°C). As such, 800°C should be the ideal temperature for synthesizing magnetic materials. On the other hand, the x m of the materials resulted from S-FeNi-LDH were much higher than those of the samples synthesized from FeNi-LDH, and even more than ten times larger than that of the magnetite reported in literature [19,27]. Therefore, the reutilization method adopted in this work would be a facile way for preparing magnetic materials with strong magnetism. 3.3 Photo-Fenton degradation results 3.3.1 Effect of solution pH on photo-Fenton degradation of OII Visible light assisted Fenton-like degradation of OII was carried out to test the catalytic activities of the obtained materials. Noteworthily, the magnetism of the materials could provide great convenience in catalysts separation. S-FeNi-800 was selected as an example (due to its best magnetism) to test the catalytic activity in OII degradation under initial solution pH of 3–7 (i.e., without further adjusting solution pH after the addition of catalyst). Both the adsorption and decolorization kinetics were examined at first. The adsorption results showed that the adsorbed OII amounts on S-FeNi-800 decreased as pH value increase from 3 to 7 (Fig. 7 a), and a pronounced decrease of adsorbed amount was observed from pH of 3 to 4. The adsorption differences should be mainly ascribed to the effects of surface protonation/deprotonation as S-FeNi-800 had an IEP of 3.63 (Table 2). The protonation effect (a positive Zeta potential) greatly favored the adsorption of anions (OII) onto the surface of S-FeNi-800 at pH of 3; at pH of 4–7, the increase of deprotonation effect (decrease of Zeta potential) resulted in the decrease of adsorbed OII amount. The degradation results showed that increasing the initial solution pH weakened the decolorization ability (Fig. 7b). OII could be quickly degraded within 40min at pH 3. However, 1.5–3.5h were needed to reach decolorization rates over 90.0% under initial pH of 4–6, and at pH 7 the decolorization could only reach 68.0% after 4h (Table 3 , Fig. 7b). The better degradation properties might be ascribed to the better adsorption capacities as showed above as good adsorption property could favor the degradation of organic contaminants [28]. On the other hand, the leaching of metal cations and the mineralization rates of OII were further determined (Table 3). Low concentrations of Fe/Ni cations under initial pH of 4–7 were leached, but quite high leaching rates were observed at pH 3. As such, the OII degradation experiments carried out under pH of 4–7 should be better in terms of reducing cations dissolution. Similar leaching concentrations of Fe/Ni cations to that of the degradation experiments were showed when dispersed S-FeNi-800 in water without H2O2 and irradiation (under pH 3 and 4) (Fig. S6). These results indicated that the high leaching concentrations of Fe/Ni species should be mainly caused by the interactions (dissolution or reactions) of Fe/Ni species with H+ in acidic conditions. With respect to mineralization rates, the results revealed that degradation at pH 3 had the best efficiency reaching 59.2%, but it was only 20.2–26.0% for the degradations at pH of 4–6 when decolorization rate over 90.0% (Table 3). However, it could be improved by increasing the oxidant amount [29], since the concentration of H2O2 was only 5mmol/L. Besides, increasing reaction times might work as well as the degradation at pH 4–6 was much slower than that at pH 3. 3.3.2 Photo-Fenton degradation of OII by various samples To reduce Fe/Ni leaching while retained the high OII decolorization, pH 4 was selected for examining the catalytic activities of the materials. Here FeNi-800 and S-FeNi-800 were firstly selected as representatives to compare the catalytic activities of the materials obtained from FeNi-LDH and S-FeNi-LDH (Fig. 8 ). The OII adsorption results showed that both of these two samples presented limited removal rates (<7.0%, Fig. 8a), which implied that decolorization should mainly depend on degradation rather than adsorption. FeNi-800 could only slightly improve the catalytic activity comparing to H2O2, while much better improvement was achieved by S-FeNi-800 (Fig. 8b). Similar adsorption and degradation results were obtained as well on the rest of the samples (Fig. S7). As such, the materials obtained from S-FeNi-LDH had higher catalytic activities than these from FeNi-LDH. On the other hand, heating temperature seemed to only slightly affect the catalytic activity, and the samples obtained from different temperature had close decolorization efficiency (Fig. S7). Cycle experiments of S-FeNi-800 at pH 4 showed that the decolorization rates of OII were 92.0%, 92.5%, and 90.8% after 1.5h for cycle 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Fig. S8). As such, the materials made from S-FeNi-LDH should have high stabilities. 3.3.3 Effect of OII loading amount on S-FeNi-LDH in OII degradation About 2g of FeNi-LDH were added into 0.1L of 2–5g/L OII solution under vigorous stirring at room temperature for 6h to generate the S-FeNi-LDH. Three samples were generated with OII adsorbed amount of 87.4, 115.8, and 208.3mg/g, respectively. The S-FeNi-LDHs were heated at 800°C; the products were named as S-FeNi87.4-800, S–FeNi115.8-800, and S-FeNi208.3-800, respectively. S-FeNi264.6-800 (i.e., S-FeNi-800) was compared as well. The OII degradation results (at pH of 4) showed that the OII degradation efficiency was improved as the OII adsorbed amount increase (Fig. 9 ). On the other hand, however, even the sample with least efficiency (i.e., S-FeNi87.4-800) had a much higher catalytic activity than the heated materials made from FeNi-LDH (Fig. S7). 3.3.4 Degradation kinetics and possible effects of Ni0 and Fe0 species In heterogeneous Fenton/photo-Fenton catalysis system, zero-order (Eq. (1)) and pseudo-first-order (Eq. (2)) degradation kinetics were generally utilized to analyze the degradations [30–32]. (1) C 0 − C t = k app t (2) −ln(Ct /C 0)= k app t where C 0 is the initial concentration of OII, Ct is the concentration of OII at time “t”, k app is the kinetic rate constant (min−1). The fitting results indicated that all the kinetics of degradations of OII under pH of 3–6 by S-FeNi-600, S-FeNi-800, and S-FeNi-1000 fitted pretty well with Eq. (1) (Fig. 10 a, Fig. S9) with a k app of 2.8425, 1.2236, 0.4751, and 0.4038min−1 respectively for degradation at pH of 3–6, which implied these degradation processes should follow the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism (LH; i.e., reaction of adsorbed contaminant molecule with OH produced on catalyst surface) [30–33]. However, at initial pH of 7 the degradation kinetics preferred to follow the Eq. (2) (R 2 =0.994) (Fig. 10b), suggesting the following of Eley–Rideal mechanism (ER; i.e., reaction of dissolved contaminant molecule with OH produced on catalyst surface) [30–33], in agreement with the results reported by Liang et al., when using magnetite as catalyst [33]. The following of LH or ER mechanism was mainly ascribed to the differences in adsorption properties toward OII of the catalysts under various pH. For better understanding the effect of Ni0 to the degradation, control experiment of using nickel (Ni0) powder (AR, >99.99%) as catalyst was carried out. The degradation results demonstrated that it presented no obvious influence or weak improvement in OII degradation at pH 3 and 4, but could significantly inhibit the Fenton reaction under pH 6 (Fig. S10). On the other hand, the existence of Ni0 could provide great convenience in catalyst separation because of its magnetism. With respect to Fe0, it could promote the electron transfer (Fe0 +Fe3+ →Fe2+) in the interface of Fe0 (Ni3Fe) and Fe3O4, and thus enhance the contaminants degradation [34,35]. 4 Conclusions The present study indicated that the spent FeNi-LDH could be reutilized to synthesize magnetic catalysts. Structural characterization results of these materials obtained from spent FeNi-LDH demonstrated that Fe and Ni elements could be reduced by OII via thermal treatment in N2 atmosphere, and thus formed the functional materials composing of magnetite and awaruite. Thermomagnetic curves characterization results illustrated that they possessed strong magnetism, which could provide great convenience in separation. Visible light assisted Fenton-like experiments revealed that these materials had high catalytic activities under pH of 3–6, and the degradations followed Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism. On the other hand, comparing to the heated products from FeNi-LDH (i.e., the double metal oxides) the obtained materials from spent FeNi-LDH presented much superiority, including variety in metal valences, higher amount of −OH surface group, stronger magnetism and higher Curie point, and higher catalytic activities. The results of this work demonstrated that synthesizing magnetic catalysts could be a feasible method for reutilizing the spent FeNi-LDH after adsorption of dye contaminants. coredata.dc:description: Magnetic Ni3Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst was prepared by using spent FeNi layered double hydroxide derived from the adsorption of organic dyes as precursor via heat treatment under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray diffraction results indicated that the obtained materials were composed of Ni3Fe and Fe3O4. Thermogravimetric analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and thermomagnetic curves characterization results demonstrated that Fe3+ and Ni2+ could be reduced to low valence by organic contaminants, and the obtained materials possessed strong magnetism. Visible light assisted Fenton-like experiment results showed that the obtained materials possessed high catalytic activities and the degradations at pH of 3–6 and pH 7 preferred to followed Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Eley–Rideal mechanism, respectively. In addition, the possible effects of Fe0 and Ni species were briefly discussed as well. On the other hand, comparing to the heated products of FeNi layered double hydroxide the obtained materials presented much superiority including variety in metal valences, higher amount of −OH surface group, stronger magnetism and higher Curie point, and higher catalytic activities. This work provided a facile method for reutilizing the spent layered double hydroxide adsorbent with special metal elements (e.g., Fe and Ni) as well as synthesizing functional material (e.g., catalyst).
coredata.dc:title: Visible light assisted Fenton-like degradation of Orange II on Ni3Fe/Fe3O4 magnetic catalyst prepared from spent FeNi layered double hydroxide
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
